markdownRemark.html:
Maintaining a healthy work-life balance is important when you’re a developer. Especially if you work remote. When I set up a new development environment, I create a cron job to change the default browser between work hours and ‘play’ hours. I use Chrome professionally as much of my day job is built around the Google ecosphere. But I use Firefox as my personal browser (and so should you) for several reasons, the two most important being Mozilla’s emphasis on privacy and the superior UI.

How to Create a Cron Job to Change the Default Browser

30 8 * * 1-5 xdg-settings set default-web-browser google-chrome.desktop
0 17 * * 1-5 xdg-settings set default-web-browser firefox.desktop

Cron jobs follow the ‘5 Star’ format:

Each asterisk corresponds to the following:

  1. Minute (by the hour)
  2. Hours
  3. Day (of the month)
  4. Month
  5. Day(s) (of the week)

In my snippet above, the cron job will run at 8:30AM, but only on weekdays. This will set my default browser as Chrome.

30 8 * * 1-5 xdg-settings set default-web-browser google-chrome.desktop

At 5PM, the cron job will run and set my default browser back to Firefox.

0 17 * * 1-5 xdg-settings set default-web-browser firefox.desktop

To list the cron job for the current user:

crontab- l

To edit the cron job for the current user:

crontab -e
